context: [3] There was a small portion of participants with intellectual disability for whom there were no reported difficulties in specimen collection, yet specimens were not obtained. [4] The reasons for noncollection of specimens were not available. [1] There was no evidence to suggest that inability to obtain fecal or blood specimens from participants with intellectual disability was significantly influenced by their levels of functional ability or maladaptive behavior (Table 3). [2] In contrast, the inability to perform the urea breath test was strongly positively associated with greater levels of disability and, to a lesser degree, greater levels of maladaptive behavior. [3] At baseline, more institutionalized participants did not provide a fecal specimen than previously institutionalized participants, who in turn were more likely not to provide a fecal specimen than participants who were never institutionalized (15 versus 8 versus 0%, respectively; P = 0.03), but at 12 months, there were no differences in the abilities of participants from any of the three institutional categories to provide fecal or blood specimens. [1] Table 4 shows the performance characteristics of the fecal-antigen test results compared to the serology results (including only participants or caregivers with no prior treatment, recent antibiotics, or current proton pump inhibitors) at the two time points for participants with intellectual disability and at the single time point for caregivers. [2] For the participants with intellectual disability, the sensitivities at baseline and 12 months were lower than among the caregivers (70 and 63 versus 81%, respectively), although all CI overlapped.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, urea is mentioned in relation to the urea breath test, which was found to be significantly associated with levels of disability among participants. Specifically, a greater level of disability correlated with an inability to perform the urea breath test. This suggests that urea testing may be impacted by the functional abilities of individuals with disabilities, indicating a potential relationship between urea metabolism and disability status.

This indicates a clear relationship within the context of assessing functional ability.
